title: REST APIs can never be cached
content: Compare REST and GraphQL in terms of data fetching and flexibility.
explanation: The correct answer is: REST returns fixed data structures per endpoint

options.text: REST returns fixed data structures per endpoint
GraphQL allows client to request exactly the fields needed
GraphQL cannot support real-time updates
REST APIs can never be cached

title: Reflow and repaint are the same
content: Explain how reflow and repaint affect rendering performance.
explanation: The correct answer is: Reflow recalculates layout and can trigger repaint

options.text: Reflow recalculates layout and can trigger repaint
Repaint only redraws pixels without layout calculation
Reflow and repaint are the same

content: Explain the WebSocket protocol and its benefits for real-time communication.
explanation: WebSocket establishes a persistent bidirectional connection between client and server, allowing real-time updates with lower overhead compared to HTTP polling.

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Discuss how Web Workers improve performance in web applications and provide an example use case.
explanation: Web Workers run scripts in background threads separate from the main UI thread. They are useful for CPU-intensive tasks like parsing large JSON, image processing, or data transformations without blocking the UI.

title: Preload defers resources until user interaction
content: Explain how prefetch and preload directives differ in terms of resource loading strategy.
explanation: Prefetch loads resources for future navigation, while preload ensures critical resources are fetched earlier for the current page.

options.text: Prefetch is for resources needed immediately
Preload is for resources needed immediately
Prefetch is for resources likely needed in future
Preload defers resources until user interaction

title: Client uses WebSocket connection for continuous streaming
content: Explain how long-polling works for real-time updates.
explanation: Long-polling keeps an HTTP request open until the server has data, then immediately sends a new request for the next update.

options.text: Client repeatedly sends requests at a fixed interval
Client sends a request, server responds only when new data is available, then client repeats
Client uses WebSocket connection for continuous streaming

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Explain optimistic updates and when they are used.
explanation: Optimistic updates immediately update the UI assuming the server request will succeed. If the request fails, the UI is reverted. It improves perceived responsiveness.

title: They increase architectural complexity
content: Explain the concept of micro-frontends and their trade-offs.
explanation: Micro-frontends split the UI into smaller, independently deployable apps. They improve scalability but increase complexity.

options.text: Micro-frontends allow independent teams to build and deploy parts of the UI
Micro-frontends always simplify performance optimization
They increase architectural complexity

title: SSG cannot be cached on CDN.
content: Compare CSR, SSR, and SSG in terms of performance, SEO, and user experience.
explanation: CSR is good for highly interactive apps, SSR helps SEO-driven apps like e-commerce, and SSG is ideal for blogs, docs, and marketing sites.

options.text: CSR loads JavaScript first and renders in the browser; SSR renders HTML on the server per request; SSG pre-renders HTML at build time.
options.explanation: CSR delays first render but enables rich interactivity; SSR improves SEO and first load but adds server cost; SSG is best for static content with CDN delivery.

options.text: CSR is faster than SSR in all cases.
SSG cannot be cached on CDN.

title: Both approaches are identical
content: Describe the difference between optimistic and pessimistic updates in state management.
explanation: Optimistic updates update UI immediately before server confirmation. Pessimistic updates wait for server response.

options.text: Optimistic update: update UI before server confirms
Pessimistic update: update UI after server confirms
Both approaches are identical

title: This is incorrect. Please refer to system design best practices.
content: Describe how virtual DOM improves rendering performance in frontend frameworks.
explanation: The virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of the UI. Instead of updating the real DOM directly, frameworks update the virtual DOM and compute the minimal changes, which are then applied to the real DOM.
